ğŸ¨ 1. Layout Structure (Universal SaaS Admin Pattern)
Sidebar Navigation

Fixed vertical sidebar on the left
Collapsible mode (full width + compact icons)
Clear hierarchy with section titles and icons
Active item highlighted with brand color or subtle accent

Top Bar

Horizontal bar at the top of the content area
Contains page title, search input, quick actions, and user menu
Slight shadow or elevation to differentiate from content

Main Content Area

Uses cards, tables, grids, or lists depending on context
Content organized with generous spacing (8â€‘point spacing system)
Breadcrumbs optional for multiâ€‘level navigation


ğŸ¨ 2. Color Palette (Neutral & Accessible)
Primary Color

A single bold and modern color (e.g., indigo, blue, teal)

Neutral Colors

Light background: #F9FAFB or similar
Card/Surface color: #FFFFFF
Borders and dividers: #E5E7EB
Text primary: #111827
Text secondary: #6B7280

State Colors

Success: green tone
Warning: amber tone
Error: red tone

Ensure compliance with WCAG AA contrast ratios.

Recommended characteristics:

Sansâ€‘serif font
Semiâ€‘bold for headings
Regular weight for body text
Font sizes:

Headings: 20â€“24px
Subheadings: 16â€“18px
Body text: 14â€“15px
Labels/captions: 12px



Use consistent typographic scale.

ğŸ“¦ 4. Components (Generic Descriptions)
Cards

Use for visual content or grouped data
Include title, description, and action area
Subtle shadow or border for elevation

Tables

Useful for large data sets
Support sorting, filtering, and bulk actions
Optional sticky header for better scanning

Forms

Twoâ€‘column layout on desktop, single column on mobile
Clear section grouping with headings
Inline validation with clear error messages
Large, accessible tap targets

Buttons

Primary button for main action
Secondary outline or ghost buttons for supporting actions
Destructive actions use danger color


ğŸ§­ 5. Navigation & Information Architecture

Keep primary actions visible and consistently placed
Use breadcrumbs for deep navigation
Collapse secondary or advanced options to reduce clutter
Provide search for global or contextâ€‘specific content


âš™ï¸ 6. Interaction Patterns

Buttons and inputs respect minimum 44px touch targets
Hover and focus states for all interactive elements
Modals used only for critical or destructive actions
Toast notifications for nonâ€‘blocking feedback
Autoâ€‘save optional for form-heavy interfaces


ğŸ“± 7. Responsiveness

Mobile-first layout
Flexible grid system
Sidebar collapses automatically on small screens
Tables switch to card view or horizontal scroll


ğŸšï¸ 8. Spacing & Layout Rules
Use an 8â€‘point system:

4 / 8 / 16 / 24 / 32 px spacing
Maintain consistent padding inside components
Align content using a standardized grid or layout system


ğŸ§© 9. Iconography & Visual Language

Use a consistent icon family
Icons should be simple and outline-based
Only use icons to reinforce meaning, not replace text
Keep imagery clean, minimal, and supportiveâ€”not dominant


ğŸ’¡ 10. General UX Principles

Prioritize clarity over decoration
Minimize cognitive load with a clean layout
Provide predictable interaction patterns
Use consistent terminology across the interface
Avoid unnecessary animations; keep transitions subtle
